question: Your golf ball lands on a soft part of the course and becomes embedded (or plugged) in its own pitch mark. According to the rules of golf, what are you entitled to do?*

choices.text: Play the ball as it lies without any relief.
Mark the spot, lift the ball, clean it, and drop it as near as possible to where it lay but not nearer the hole, without penalty.
Pick up the ball, clean it, and drop it within one club-length, no closer to the hole, without penalty.
Replace the ball in its original embedded position after cleaning it, with no penalty.

explanation: When a ball becomes embedded in its own pitch mark on the fairway or in the rough, the rules of golf allow for free relief. This means you can mark the spot where the ball lay, lift and clean the ball, then drop it without penalty within one club-length of the nearest point of relief, but not nearer to the hole. This rule helps to address situations where the ball is unplayable due to course conditions.
